question: How is the harp’s presence in British history connected to David’s musical practices?
gold_answer: David played the lyre and used to suspend the kinnor, which is rendered as harp and is in the Anglo-Saxon manuscript.
llm_answer: The harp is called _cithara anglica_ in British history, suggesting that it was regarded as a pre-eminently British instrument.

context.text: with a mallet. This is stated in a historical essay written by Ixtlilxochitl, a native of Mexico and of royal descent, who lived in the beginning of the seventeenth century, and who may be supposed to have been familiar with the musical practices of his countrymen. But whether the sonorous metal alluded to was a gong or a bell is not clear from the vague record transmitted to us. That the bell was known to the Peruvians appears to be no longer doubtful, since a small copper specimen has been found in one of the old Peruvian tombs. This interesting relic is now deposited in the museum at Lima. M. de Castelnau has published a drawing of it, which is here reproduced. The Peruvians called their bells _chanrares_; it remains questionable whether this name did not designate rather the so-called horse bells, which were certainly known to the Mexicans who called them _yotl_. It is noteworthy that these _yotl_ are found figured in the picture-writings representing the various objects which the Aztecs used to pay as tribute to their sovereigns. The collection of Mexican antiquities in the British museum contains a cluster of yotl-bells. Being nearly round, they closely resemble the _Schellen_ which the Germans are in the habit of affixing to their horses, particularly in the winter when they are driving their noiseless sledges. [Illustration]

_cithara_, _chelys_, _testudo_, _fidis_ (or _fides_), and _cornu_. The name _cornu_ was given to the lyre when the sides of the frame terminated at the top in the shape of two horns. The _barbitos_ was a kind of lyre with a large body, which gave the instrument somewhat the shape of the Welsh _crwth_. The _psalterium_ was a kind of lyre of an oblong square shape. Like most of the Roman lyres, it was played with a rather large plectrum. The _trigonum_ was the same as the Greek _trigonon_, and was probably originally derived from Egypt. It is recorded that a certain musician of the name of Alexander Alexandrinus was so admirable a performer upon it that when exhibiting his skill in Rome he created the greatest _furore_. Less common, and derived from Asia, were the _sambuca_ and _nablia_, the exact construction of which is unknown. The flute, _tibia_, was originally made of the shin bone, and had a mouth-hole and four finger-holes. Its shape was retained even when, at a later period, it was constructed of other substances than bone. The _tibia gingrina_ consisted of a long and thin tube of reed with a mouth-hole at the side of one end. The _tibia

Romans we have the first well-authenticated proof of musical instruments having been introduced into Europe from Asia. The Romans in their conquests undoubtedly made their musical instruments known, to some extent, also in western Europe. But the Greeks and Romans are not the only nations which introduced eastern instruments into Europe. The Phœnicians at an early period colonized Sardinia, and traces of them are still to be found on that island. Among these is a peculiarly constructed double-pipe, called _lionedda_ or _launedda_. Again, at a much later period the Arabs introduced several of their instruments into Spain, from which country they became known in France, Germany, and England. Also the crusaders, during the eleventh and twelfth centuries, may have helped to familiarize the western European nations with instruments of the east. CHAPTER V. THE CHINESE. Allowing for any exaggeration as to chronology, natural to the lively imagination of Asiatics, there is no reason to doubt that the Chinese possessed long before our Christian era musical instruments to which they attribute a fabulously high antiquity. There is an ancient tradition, according to which they obtained their musical scale from a miraculous bird, called foung-hoang, which appears to have been a sort of phœnix. When Confucius, who lived about B.C. 500, happened to hear on a certain occasion some Chinese music, he became so greatly enraptured that he could

work _cithara teutonica_, while the harp is called _cithara anglica_; from which it would appear that the former was regarded as pre-eminently a German instrument. Possibly its name may have been originally _chrotta_ and the continental nations may have adopted it from the Celtic races of the British isles, dropping the guttural sound. This hypothesis is, however, one of those which have been advanced by some musical historians without any satisfactory evidence. [Illustration] [Illustration] We engrave also another representation of David playing on the _rotta_, from a psalter of the seventh century in the British museum (Cott. Vesp. A. I). According to tradition, this psalter is one of the manuscripts which were sent by pope Gregory to St. Augustine. The instrument much resembles the lyre in the hand of the musician (see p. 22) who is supposed to be a Hebrew of the time of Joseph. In the _rotta_ the ancient Asiatic lyre is easily to be recognized. An illumination of king David playing the _rotta_ forms the frontispiece of a manuscript of the eighth century preserved in the cathedral library of Durham; and which is musically interesting inasmuch as it represents a _rotta_ of an oblong square shape like that just noticed and resembling the Welsh _crwth_. It has only five strings which the performer twangs with his

expressions, which cannot be properly rendered on any other instrument, however superior in some respects it may be to the pianoforte. Thus also the improvements which have been made during the present century in the construction of our brass instruments, and the invention of several new brass instruments, have evidently been not without influence upon the conceptions displayed in our modern orchestral works. Imperfect though this essay may be it will probably have convinced the reader that a reference to the history of the music of different nations elucidates many facts illustrative of our own musical instruments, which to the unprepared observer must appear misty and impenetrable. In truth, it is with this study as with any other scientific pursuit. The unassisted eye sees only faint nebulæ where with the aid of the telescope bright stars are revealed. INDEX. Al-Farabi, a great performer on the lute, 57 American Indian instruments, 59, 77 " value of inquiry, 59 " trumpets, 67 " theories as to origin from musical instruments, 80 Arab instruments very numerous, 56 Archlute, 109, 115 Ashantee trumpet, 2 Asor explained, 19 Assyrian instruments, 16 “Aulos,” 32 Bagpipe, Hebrew, 23 " Greek, 31 " Celtic, 119 Barbiton, 31, 34 Bells, Hebrew, 25 " Peruvian, 75 " and ringing,

beating time and for rhythmical purposes. The slips being banded together at one end could be expanded somewhat like a fan. The Chinese state that they used the _tchoung-tou_ for writing upon before they invented paper. The _ou_, of which we give a woodcut, likewise an ancient Chinese instrument of percussion and still in use, is made of wood in the shape of a crouching tiger. It is hollow, and along its back are about twenty small pieces of metal, pointed, and in appearance not unlike the teeth of a saw. The performer strikes them with a sort of plectrum resembling a brush, or with a small stick called _tchen_. Occasionally the _ou_ is made with pieces of metal shaped like reeds. [Illustration] The ancient _ou_ was constructed with only six tones which were attuned thus--_f_, _g_, _a_, _c_, _d_, _f_. The instrument appears to have become deteriorated in the course of time; for, although it has gradually acquired as many as twenty-seven pieces of metal, it evidently serves at the present day more for the production of rhythmical noise than for the execution of any melody. The modern _ou_ is made of a species of wood called _kieou_ or _tsieou_: and the tiger rests generally on a hollow wooden pedestal about three feet six inches long, which serves as a sound-board. [Illustration] The

upon the real meaning of which much diversity of opinion prevails. _Jobel_ is by some commentators classed with the trumpets, but it is by others believed to designate a loud and cheerful blast of the trumpet, used on particular occasions. If _Jobel_ (from which _jubilare_ is supposed to be derived) is identical with the name _Jubal_, the inventor of musical instruments, it would appear that the Hebrews appreciated pre-eminently the exhilarating power of music. _Shalisbim_ is supposed to denote a triangle. _Nechiloth_, _gittith_, and _machalath_, which occur in the headings of some psalms, are also by commentators supposed to be musical instruments. _Nechiloth_ is said to have been a flute, and _gittith_ and _machalath_ to have been stringed instruments, and _machol_ a kind of flute. Again, others maintain that the words denote peculiar modes of performance or certain favourite melodies to which the psalms were directed to be sung, or chanted. According to the records of the Rabbins, the Hebrews in the time of David and Solomon possessed thirty-six different musical instruments. In the Bible only about half that number are mentioned. Most nations of antiquity ascribed the invention of their musical instruments to their gods, or to certain superhuman beings. The Hebrews attributed it to

exclusively for promoting the cultivation of music; its aim comprised the advancement of various arts, and of sciences such as history, astronomy, &c. In fact, it was an academy for general education. Probably no better evidence could be cited testifying to the remarkable intellectual attainments of the Mexican Indians before the discovery of America than this council of music. Although in some respects it appears to have resembled the board of music of the Chinese, it was planned on a more enlightened and more comprehensive principle. The Chinese “board of music,” called _Yo Poo_, is an office connected with the _Lé Poo_ or “board of rites,” established by the imperial government at Peking. The principal object of the board of rites is to regulate the ceremonies on occasions of sacrifices offered to the gods; of festivals and certain court solemnities; of military reviews; of presentations, congratulations, marriages, deaths, burials,--in short, concerning almost every possible event in social and public life. The reader is probably aware that in one of the various hypotheses which have been advanced respecting the Asiatic origin of the American Indians China is assigned to them as their ancient home. Some historians suppose them to be emigrants from Mongolia, Thibet, or Hindustan; others maintain that they are the offspring of Phœnician colonists who settled in central America. Even more curious are the arguments of certain inquirers who have no doubt whatever that the ancestors of the American Indians were the

in the Bible. The lyres at the time of Simon Maccabæus may probably be different from those which were in use about a thousand years earlier, or at the time of David and Solomon when the art of music with the Hebrews was at its zenith. There appears to be a probability that a Hebrew lyre of the time of Joseph (about 1700 B.C.) is represented on an ancient Egyptian painting discovered in a tomb at Beni Hassan,--which is the name of certain grottoes on the eastern bank of the Nile. Sir Gardner Wilkinson, in his “Manners and Customs of the Ancient Egyptians,” observes: “If, when we become better acquainted with the interpretation of hieroglyphics, the ‘Strangers’ at Beni Hassan should prove to be the arrival of Jacob’s family in Egypt, we may examine the Jewish lyre drawn by an Egyptian artist. That this event took place about the period when the inmate of the tomb lived is highly probable--at least, if I am correct in considering Osirtasen I. to be the Pharaoh the patron of Joseph; and it remains for us to decide whether the disagreement in the number of persons here introduced--thirty-seven being written over them in hieroglyphics--is a sufficient objection to their identity. It will not be foreign to the present subject to introduce those figures which are curious, if only considered as illustrative of ancient customs at that early period, and which

and the _chitarrone_. It is unnecessary to enter here into a detailed description of some other instruments which have been popular during the last three centuries, for the museum at Kensington contains specimens of many of them of which an account is given in the large catalogue of that collection. It must suffice to refer the reader to the illustrations there of the cither, virginal, spinet, clavichord, harpsichord, and other antiquated instruments much esteemed by our forefathers. Students who examine these old relics will probably wish to know something about their quality of tone. “How do they sound? Might they still be made effective in our present state of the art?” are questions which naturally occur to the musical inquirer having such instruments brought before him. A few words bearing on these questions may therefore not be out of place here. [Illustration] It is generally and justly admitted that in no other branch of the art of music has greater progress been made since the last century than in the construction of musical instruments. Nevertheless, there are people who think that we have also lost something here which might with advantage be restored. Our various instruments by being more and more perfected are becoming too much alike in quality of sound, or in that character of tone which the French call _timbre_, and the Germans _Klangfarbe_, and which professor Tyndall in his lectures on sound has translated _clang-tint_. Every musical composer knows how much more

1. **Title**: Ancient Musical Instruments
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks discusses various ancient musical instruments from different cultures, including the harp, lyre, pipes, flutes, and drums. The instruments are described in terms of their construction, shape, and usage, with examples from ancient civilizations such as the Greeks, Assyrians, and Egyptians. The texts also touch on the evolution of musical instruments and their significance in understanding the cultural and historical context of different societies. The use of musical instruments in religious and cultural practices is also mentioned, highlighting their importance in human expression and communication. The texts provide a comprehensive overview of the diversity of ancient musical instruments and their role in shaping the music of different cultures.
3. **Keywords**: Ancient Instruments, Musical History, Cultural Significance, Instrument Evolution, Historical Context

The use of instruments in different contexts, such as warfare and religious ceremonies, is also explored.
3. **Keywords**: Ancient Instruments, Musical History, Cultural Exchange

1. **Historical Musical Instruments**

The lute, in particular, is mentioned as being played in the Persian style, with a system of seventeen intervals in the compass of an octave. The carillon, a musical instrument composed of multiple bells, is also described, with its origins and evolution in European countries. The text highlights the unique characteristics of each instrument and their suitability for producing specific musical effects. The development of musical instruments has led to the creation of new musical compositions and expressions. The history of bell-ringing and peal-ringing in England is also explored, with descriptions of the techniques and instruments used.
3. **Keywords**: Historical instruments, Lute, Carillon, Organ, Musical evolution

1. **Title**: Moroccan History and Demographics
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the history and demographics of Morocco, including the Shereefian lineage, population estimates, and the distribution of various tribes and ethnic groups such as the Berbers, Arabs, and Amazirghs. The Shereefian lineage is outlined, with notable figures including Muley Ismail, Muley Abdullah, and Sidi Mohammed. The population estimates vary, with some sources suggesting the population is around 8-15 million, although these numbers are considered exaggerated. The text also touches on the geography and climate of Morocco, noting its similarity to Spain and Portugal, and the presence of the Atlas mountain range. The country's history and cultural influences are also discussed, including the presence of European refugees and the derivation of terms such as "Mauri" and "Saracini".
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Shereefian, Berbers, Arabs, Demographics

1. **Title**: Morocco and its Royal Cities
2. **Summary**: The text describes the state of Morocco and its royal cities, including Fez, Mequinez, and Tafilett, which are in decline. The country is ruled by the Shereefs, a dynasty of African blood, and the Sultan's presence is necessary to maintain allegiance in the north. The cities are characterized by their unique cultural and architectural features, such as the use of Dutch tiles and the production of wool and silk manufactures. The text also mentions the bombardment of Mogador by the French and the subsequent pillage and violence perpetrated by wild tribes. The British Consul and his wife narrowly escaped with their lives, and the city was left in a state of destruction.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Fez, Mequinez, Tafilett, Shereefs, Mogador

1. **Title**: Exploring North African Cities
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe various cities in North Africa, including Salee, Fez, and Rabat, highlighting their historical significance, architectural features, and cultural practices. These cities have been influenced by different empires and civilizations, such as the Romans, Moors, and Spanish, leaving behind a rich legacy of trade, architecture, and traditions. The texts also mention the natural surroundings, including forests, rivers, and hills, which have shaped the development of these cities. The region is home to a diverse population, including Muslims, Jews, and Christians, with a strong presence of Moorish saints and Sufi traditions.
3. **Keywords**: North Africa, Moorish Cities, Historical Trade, Islamic Architecture, Cultural Heritage

1. **Lower Canada Rebellion**
2. **Summary**: The Lower Canada Rebellion was a pivotal event in Canadian history, sparked by the Patriotes' resistance to British rule and the desire for independence. The rebellion was marked by violent clashes between the Patriotes and loyalist forces, with key events including the Battle of Lacolle and the Battle of Odelltown. The Patriotes, led by figures such as Papineau and Robert Nelson, drew inspiration from the American Revolution and sought to establish a provisional government. However, the rebellion ultimately failed, and many of its leaders were forced to flee or were captured. The British response to the rebellion was marked by brutality, with widespread burning and harrying of villages. The rebellion had significant consequences for the development of Canadian politics and identity.
3. **Keywords**: Lower Canada Rebellion, Patriotes, British Rule, Canadian History, Independence Movement

1. **Title**: Maya Civilization and Culture
2. **Summary**: The Maya civilization is discussed in relation to their cultural practices, superstitions, and traditions. Their beliefs in witchcraft, use of talismans, and reverence for certain objects are compared to those of other ancient cultures, such as the Chaldeans and Africans. The Maya language is also analyzed, with etymologies provided for various words and names. Additionally, the text describes Maya clothing, musical instruments, and funeral customs, highlighting similarities with other cultures. The author draws parallels between Maya practices and those of other civilizations, suggesting a shared human experience.
3. **Keywords**: Maya Civilization, Cultural Practices, Superstitions, Comparative Anthropology, Ancient Cultures

1. **Title**: Maya Civilization Connections
2. **Summary**: The text discusses the potential connections between the Maya civilization and other ancient cultures, including the Egyptians, Chaldeans, and Etruscans. The author highlights similarities in language, writing systems, and symbolism between these cultures, suggesting that there may have been communication and exchange between them in the distant past. The author also describes their own research and discoveries, including the deciphering of Maya inscriptions and the identification of identical characters and symbols in different cultures. The text also touches on the idea that the Maya civilization may have had roots in Atlantis, and that their language and customs show similarities with those of other ancient cultures.
3. **Keywords**: Maya Civilization, Ancient Cultures, Linguistic Connections, Symbolism, Archaeology

1. **Title**: Maya Civilization Connections

The author highlights the similarities in language, architecture, and symbolism, such as the prevalence of the number seven, between these cultures. The Maya's advanced knowledge of astronomy, mathematics, and architecture is also explored, with examples from their cities, such as Uxmal and Chichen. The author suggests that the Maya may have had a significant influence on other ancient cultures, and that their knowledge and traditions may have been shared across the ancient world.
3. **Keywords**: Maya Civilization, Ancient Cultures, Symbolism, Astronomy, Architecture

1. **Title**: Maya Civilization and Chaldean Connections
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the potential connections between the Maya civilization and the Chaldeans, with a focus on linguistic and cultural similarities. The author explores the etymology of various Chaldean deity names and their possible origins in the American Maya language. The text also touches on the history and customs of the Maya people, including their architecture, trade, and religious practices. Additionally, the author mentions the discovery of archaeological findings, such as tombs and artifacts, that provide insight into the lives of the Maya and Chaldeans. The overall theme is one of exploration and comparison between these two ancient cultures.
3. **Keywords**: Maya Civilization, Chaldean Culture, Linguistic Connections, Archaeological Findings, Ancient Trade and Religion
